value.title: Create and use custom visuals for Power BI in minutes!!
value.excerpt: Create and use custom visuals for Power BI in minutes!! If you are not able to use custom visuals from the AppStore but you still need them, you can now create your own and use them in Power BI, all of that in minutes!  In today's video, I am going to show you how you can use a custom visual we created

value.title: Create heatmaps without custom visuals in Power BI
value.excerpt: Quick tip for today: I will show you how to create a heatmap in Power BI without downloading a custom visual. value.title: DAX Fridays! #15: SWITCH
value.excerpt: Learn how to use the function SWITCH in DAX/ Powerpivot. Switch is the equivalent of IF but it has easier syntax and therefore it is easier to read. value.title: DAX Fridays! #21: USERELATIONSHIP
value.excerpt: A common example in a Power BI table is to have multiple dates, which are related to the same Date table. As you are limited to one active relationship, we need to use the DAX function USERELATIONSHIP to manage the inactive relationships.  Link to Power BI file: https://curbal.com/blog/glossary/userelationship-dax

value.title: DAX Fridays! #24: Running/ Cumulative totals (w Pareto chart)
value.excerpt: In this video I will show you how to calculate cumulative totals or running totals with DAX/ powerpivot.  We will calculate running totals with a Date and with another column (not a date).  Link to Matt's Blog post: http://exceleratorbi.com.au/cumulative-running-total-based-on-highest-value/  Link to

value.title: DAX Fridays! #7: ALL, ALLEXCEPT
value.excerpt: The function ALL returns all the rows in a table, or all the values in a column, ignoring any filters that might have been applied. This function is useful for clearing filters and creating calculations on all the rows in a table.  The function ALLEXCEPT removes all filters except the ones that have
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/q4jePhzKtbU" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: DAX Fridays! #77: GROUPBY, CURRENTGROUP
value.excerpt: In today's DAX Fridays, we will go through the DAX function GROUPBY with an example.  GROUPBY is similar as SUMMARIZE, but the difference is that in the expression part, you use DAX iterators to get your results. You can also nest GROUPBY functions to get for example the highest sales amount by country.

value.title: DAX Fridays! #80: DATESBETWEEN
value.excerpt: In todays video we are going to cover the DAX function DATESBETWEEN.  DATESBETWEEN function allows you to calculate amounts between two dates you specify.   For example, if you want to calculate the sum of sales between two specific dates, this is the perfect function for you.  You can "hardcode" the

value.title: Power BI vs Excel: When you should use each tool
value.excerpt: Which tool is best? Power BI or Excel?  Well, it depends on what you are trying to do. Both tools have unique strengths and limitations and in this video I will try to show both.  Hopefully after watching this video, you will have a better understanding of both tools and will know when to use which depending

value.title: Running totals in power query??? Yes, you can :)

Also, I will show you how List.Range work, really cool function :)  Here you can download all the pbix files: https://curbal.com/donwload-center
